sen.j: 生野奉行（いくのぶぎょう）は、織田信長、豊臣秀吉および徳川幕府により置かれ、生野銀山を管理した。
sen.e: Ikuno Bugyo (Ikuno Magistrate) was administered under Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI as well as the Tokugawa Shogunate, and it controlled the area of Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine.
Ikuno Bugyo was administered under Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI as well as the Tokugawa Shogunate, and it controlled the area of Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine.

sen.e: Ikuno Bugyo was administered under Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI as well as the Tokugawa Shogunate, and it controlled the area of Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine.

sen.j: 1716年（亨保元年）、生野銀山の産出量減少のため、生野代官（いくのだいかん）に組織変更された。
sen.e: In 1716, due to the decrease in the volume of silver production at Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine, the Ikuno Magistrate was reorganized to the Local Governor of Ikuno.
In 1716, due to the decrease in the volume of silver production at Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine, the Ikuno bugyo was reorganized to the Ikuno daikan (the regional officer of Ikuno).

sen.j: 奉行所・代官所は、現在の兵庫県朝来市生野町口銀谷の生野小学校付近にあった。
sen.e: The magistrate's office was located near Ikuno Elementary School of Ikuno-cho, Kuchiganaya, Asago City, Hyogo Prefecture.
The bugyosho (magistrate's office)/daikansho (regional officer's office) was located near Ikuno Elementary School located in Kuchiganaya, Ikuno-cho, Asago City, Hyogo Prefecture.

sen.j: 江戸時代の生野奉行は11代、代官に改組後は28人が勤めた。
sen.e: 11 magistrates served at the Ikuno Magistrate and after the reorganization took place, 28 local governors served at the local governor's office during the Edo Period.
11 bugyo served at the Ikuno bugyosho and after the reorganization took place, 28 daikan served at the Ikuno daikansho during the Edo period.

sen.j: 代官には旗本が任命され、生野銀山の後背地となっていた但馬国、播磨国、美作国の天領も統治した。
sen.e: A Hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was appointed as the local governor, and he administered Tajima Province, Harima Province, as well as Mimasaka Province which were the hinterlands of Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine.

A hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was appointed as the daikan, and he administered Tajima Province, Harima Province, as well as Mimasaka Province which were the hinterlands of Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine.

sen.j: なお、統治規模は但馬国最大の藩である出石藩よりも大きく、江戸時代初期は5万2千石、江戸時代末期には8万2千石に達していた。
sen.e: Furthermore, the scale under administration was larger than the area ruled by the Izushi Domain, which was the largest Domain in Tajima Province, and during the initial years of the Edo Period, the area totaled to 52,000 koku and at the end of the Edo Period to 82,000 koku.

Furthermore, the scale under administration was larger than the area ruled by the Izushi Domain, which was the largest domain in Tajima Province, and during the initial years of the Edo period, the area totaled to 52,000 koku (an unit of assessed crop yields of the land [1 koku: about 180 liter], which was also used to express the size of the land) and at the end of the Edo period to 82,000 koku.

sen.j: 江戸時代後期の1863年（文久3年）10月には生野の変での挙兵によって代官所が占領されてしまっている。
sen.e: The local governor's office was taken over during the uprising of the Ikuno Incident which took place in October, 1863, towards the end of the Edo Period.
The daikansho was taken over during the uprising of the Ikuno Incident which took place in October, 1863, towards the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 生野の変は、天誅組の変とともに明治維新の導火線となったと評価されている。
sen.e: It has been thought that the Ikuno Incident along with the Tenchu-gumi Incident served as the precursor to for the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 明治維新後の生野代官所支配地は、府中裁判所、久美浜県、生野県となった後、豊岡県、姫路県、北条県に分割・編入された。
sen.e: The Ikuno magistrate's office after the Meiji Restoration became, in the order of, Fuchu Court, and then Kumihama Prefecture and finally as Ikuno Prefecture, and they were either partitioned or incorporated into Toyooka Prefecture, Himeji Prefecture, and Hokujo Prefecture.

The area that the Ikuno daikansho ruled after the Meiji Restoration was, in the order of, Fuchu Court, then Kumihama Prefecture and finally as Ikuno Prefecture, and they were either partitioned or incorporated into Toyooka Prefecture, Himeji Prefecture, and Hokujo Prefecture.

sen.j: 現在は、兵庫県および岡山県の一部となっている。
